Introduction
Steven A Trewick currently works in the Wildlife & Ecology Group, School of Agriculture and Environment, Massey University. Steven does research in evolutionary ecology with current projects on spatial genetics of invasive mammal species, insect-plant interactions, alpine adaptation and climate change, reproductive strategies and island evolution.

Projects

Projects (6)
Grasshopper-Host Plant associations in the New Zealand alpine grasslands
Project
In some New Zealand alpine grasslands, multiple alpine grasshoppers co-occur without competitive exclusion. This suggests the possibility of niche differentiation (i.e., in terms of habitat and host plants) and species-specific mate recognition system. Therefore, the purpose of this project is to investigate the ecology of the New Zealand alpine grasshoppers by looking at their habitat and host plant ecology and investigate mate recognition system by exploring their chemical ecology (e.g., use of pheromone). This study will increase our knowledge of the native diversity in grasslands, providing valuable information for their conservation and management.
View

Project
View
Integrating fossils and genetics of living molluscs
Project
We are studying the evolution of extant species that are represented in the New Zealand fossil record. By combining molecular phylogenetics with geometric morphometrics we can determine species boundaries and evolutionary relationships. Well integrated paleontological data and extant organisms of New Zealand monophyletic lineages allows us to model morphological evolution and test the predictions of punctuated equilibrium.
